instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins twice but no chime, no screen
threads.message:
Hello,

First general question... why can't search the forum based on board numbers? ;-)

Second, I have that <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that someone has already reworked and cleaned so difficult to tell if any damaged has been done on it.
However what I can tell is that I am getting the fan to spin only twice or once (when it should do thrice)
All the power rails are present, as well as <SIGNAL>SYS_PWROK_R</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL>
CPU gets hot.

Any hint please on where to look in this case?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins twice but no chime, no screen
threads.message:
You can, just omit the - as that is search syntax for ignore.

So search for 820 3115 or even just 3115.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> means 820 and NEVER 3115.

Welcome!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins twice but no chime, no screen
threads.message: Check termination resistors from <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> to the SMC

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins twice but no chime, no screen
threads.message:
Hi Duke,

I did check these and they measure all fine.
I've also reflowed the SMC in case of a bad connection underneath it but no cigar.

I also tried a different BIOS chip.

Any other idea please?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins twice but no chime, no screen
threads.message: Not much can be done. Check resistors and traces again from <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> to the SMC. Inspect board for corroded/missing parts

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins twice but no chime, no screen
threads.message:
That board can stay running forever, fan spinning however when I try to measure the voltages near <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> the board just dies.

Could I be on a hint or is it a normal behavior? (thinking it could create a slight voltage fluctuation which would cause the CPU to stop...)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins twice but no chime, no screen
threads.message:
Is normal that it shuts down when probing around <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>. But why probing around <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, if you have CPU Vcore all power sequence is working.

Check <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> area and termination resistors and the traces.
